contents.name: Barbarian: Path of the Short Fuse

data.name: Firearms
entries: A firearm is a gunpowder powered weapon, that uses explosions to propel projectiles at dangerously high speeds. They are martial weapons for the purposes of spells or effects that require one, but you need the firearm proficiency specifically in order to be considered proficient with them.

entries.name: Firearm Properties
entries: Some firearm properties ask for a saving throw. The DC of these saving throws is equal to: {@b 8 + your proficiency bonus + your dexterity modifier.}

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: All firearms require ammunition to make an attack. Each firearm uses its own unique ammunition and is generally sold or crafted in batches listed in the Ammo column of the firearms chart next to the price. This ammunition is destroyed on use.

entries.name: Concealed
entries: The weapon is concealed as something else, perhaps a cane or lighter. If you attack a creature with a concealed weapon, and they do not know it is a concealed weapon, your attack roll is made with advantage.

entries.name: Explosive
entries: Upon a hit, everything within 5 ft of the target must make a Dexterity saving throw or suffer fire damage equal to the weaponâ€™s damage, reduced by one damage die. If the weapon misses, the ammunition fails to detonate, or bounces away harmlessly before doing so. If the weapon misfires, you take 1d4 damage of the weapon's type

entries.name: Fused
entries: A firearm with the fused property can be used as either a firearm or another kind of weapon. If the firearm misfires, you can still use it as the listed weapon.

entries.name: Lethal
entries: When you roll a number on the damage die equal to the lethal score or lower, you can reroll that die. You must take the new roll. This property cannot be applied to a weapon that has the explosive property, and cannot be used on the damage rolls for the special attacks of the rapid and scatter properties.

entries.name: Melee
entries: You can make a melee weapon attack using this weapon, with a reach of 5 feet. This melee weapon attack uses Strength to determine your attack and damage, and your misfire score increases by 2 for the attack. If the weapon has the fused property, you add the firearm damage to the fused weapon's normal melee damage.

entries.name: Misfire
entries: henever you score a critical miss on an attack roll with a firearm, the weapon misfires. The attack misses, and the weapon cannot be used again until you spend 1 attack or 1 action to unjam it. Each time the weapon misfires, it's damage is reduced by it's misfire score. If a firearm misfires three times between rests, it breaks and cannot be used at all.

During a short or long rest, you can repair your firearm, removing the damage reduction from any misfires. To repair your firearm, you must make a successful Intelligence (Tinkerâ€™s Tools) check (DC equal to 8 + misfire score). If your weapon is broken entirely, it costs a quarter of the cost of the firearm to repair it to a functional state.
Creatures who use a firearm without being proficient score a critical miss on a roll of 1 or 2.

entries.name: Rapid
entries: By firing three pieces of ammunition instead of one, you can make a special attack with this weapon. Target one creature in your weapon's normal range. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw or suffer your weapon damage. Additionally, roll a d20. If you roll equal to or below your weapon's misfire score, the weapon misfires and the special attack fails.

entries.name: Reload
entries: The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm, and you must be holding it.

entries.name: Scatter
entries: By loading a round of Buckshot ammunition, you can make a special attack with this weapon. All creatures in a cone equal to the weaponâ€™s normal range must make a Dexterity saving throw or suffer your weaponâ€™s damage, reduced by one damage die. Additionally, roll a d20. If you roll equal to or below twice your weapon's misfire score, the weapon misfires and the special attack fails.

entries.name: Scoped
entries: By spending 1 attack or 1 action with this weapon, you can aim down it's scoped sights to gain advantage on the next attack roll you make with the weapon at it's long range. You cannot use this property if you have moved during that turn, and lose the advantage if you move before firing.

entries.name: Steadied
entries: As an action while prone, you can steady this weapon. While prone, you do not have disadvantage on ranged attack rolls with this weapon due to being prone, or attacking at the weapon's long range.

entries.name: Silenced
entries: Wisdom (Perception) checks made to determine where a shot was fired from with this weapon are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: Worn
entries: A worn weapon takes an action to don or doff, usually being worked into or strapped to a piece of armor. While donned, it can be used without taking up a hand.

entries.name: Bullets
entries: Bullets are the ammunition used by all firearms. For their cost and batch size, check the ammo column of the firearms charts. Each firearm uses a specific kind of bullet, so you cannot load bullets made for one firearm into another. A single batch of any kind of bullets weighs 1 pound.

entries.name: Standard
entries: Standard ammunition has no special effects, and has the normal cost of the ammunition to produce.

entries.name: Buckshot
entries: The scatter property requires Buckshot ammunition, which fires several small pellets in a scattered array. They cost three times the standard cost of the ammunition to produce.

entries.name: Silvered
entries: Some monsters that have immunity or resistance to nonmagical weapons are susceptible to silver weapons, so cautious adventurers invest extra coin to plate their weapons with silver. You can silver ten bullets of any kind for 100 gp.

data.name: Crafting Firearms
entries: Through the Gunsmith feature of the Gunslinger Subclass, you are able to create firearms from scratch. Creating a firearm is an extensive process, requiring that you go through three important steps before the firearm is completed; Planning, Prototyping, and Production. The cost of crafting your firearm is equal to it's listed cost for purchase, and is divided between the stages, as described below.

entries.name: Planning
entries: The {@b Planning} stage of firearm crafting involves theory crafting, drawing up schematics and immersing yourself in draft after draft of theoretical designs. This stage usually accounts for around a quarter of the firearm's cost. If you have created this type of firearm before, you can skip to the production stage immediately.

You must spend a week, where at least two hours each day are spent focusing on the task of designing the firearm. This counts as light activity for the purposes of a long rest. At the end of the week, roll an Intelligence (Tinker's Tools) check. If you spend twice as long to plan, you have advantage on this ability check. The check's DC starts at 12, and is modified by the following:

rows: If the weapon has more than one damage die.
If the weapon has a misfire score above 1.
If the weapon has any other properties besides misfire, reload and lethal.
If the weapon is one handed.
If the weapon has a reload score above 1.
If the weapon does an alternative damage type to piercing.
If the weapon is one-handed and has a range above (60/240).
If the weapon is two-handed and has a range above (120/480)

entries: If you fail, you spend an eighth of your firearm's total cost, and must try again. Otherwise, you spend a quarter of your firearm's total on the draft.

entries.name: Prototyping
entries: The {@b Prototyping} stage of firearm crafting involves more hands on work, involving assembling a temporary model of the firearm and testing it before making refinements before production. This stage usually accounts for around a quarter of the firearm's cost.

You must spend two weeks, where at least two hours each day are spent focusing on the task of prototyping the firearm. At the end of the two weeks, make an attack roll and a damage roll with the firearm, ignoring the lethal property. If you misfire, or roll a 1 on any of the damage die, you must spend an eighth of the firearm's total cost repairing and adjusting the prototype to try again.
If you spend twice as long to prototype, you make the prototyping attack roll with advantage.
Alternatively, you can spend four times as long prototyping to also gain a reroll of the first 1 rolled on a damage die during this process, keeping the new roll.
If you succeed, you spend a quarter of the firearm's total cost and can move onto the production step.

entries.name: Planning
entries: The {@b Production} stage of firearm crafting is much less mentally involved, though it still takes finesse and skill that only a Gunsmith possess. This stage usually accounts for around half of the firearm's cost.
You must spend a week, where at least two hours each day are spent focusing on the task of constructing the firearm. Constructing a firearm costs half of the firearm's total cost.

entries.name: Crafting Bullets
entries: During a long rest, you can make a Dexterity (Tinker's Tools) check. If the ammunition you are crafting costs more than 5 gold per batch, the DC is 15. Otherwise it is 10.
If you stay up for twice as long during your long rest, making a Constitution saving throw to avoid exhaustion as normal, you make this ability check with advantage.
On a success, you craft one batch of ammunition provided you have materials equal to half of the ammunition's cost.

data.name: Advanced Firearms

entries.caption: Advanced Firearms
rows: Melee, rapid, reload 1, misfire 3, attached (wrist), lethal 1
Two-handed, reload 1, misfire 2, scoped, steadied, lethal 2

entries: Not all firearms are created equally - some are far more technically advanced, and far more deadly as a result. Some might have enough range to shoot someone before they can even spot you, or might be discreet or not require the use of your hands. These advanced firearms require {@b Advanced} forms of {@b Planning}, {@b Prototyping} and {@b Production}.
